reasoning: Centrality: The critique targets a key step in Section 2 (“Future catastrophes are easy” even in common-sense utopia), which supports the broader “eutopia is fragile / narrow target” thesis, but it doesn’t engage the later Section 3 value-function argument; so undermining this would weaken but not collapse the whole position. Strength: The equilibrium/strategic-actors point plausibly reduces how ‘default’ some pathologies are (especially blatant exploitation/disenfranchisement of digital beings), but it doesn’t show that bargaining reliably tracks moral truth or avoids large value loss under many moral views (e.g., population ethics scale, subtle welfare-theory errors, value lock-in, rights assignments that are stable yet morally wrong). Many failures could persist as stable equilibria. Thus it partially weakens the “easy mistake” framing rather than refuting it. Correctness: It’s broadly true that high-stakes issues become salient and contested and that equilibria/institutions can constrain extremes; however the implicit suggestion that this systematically pushes away from ‘catastrophic’ moral error is overstated and contestable. Clarity: The argument is readable, identifies the attacked claim, and gives a mechanism (equilibrium selection via bargaining/institutions), though it remains somewhat hand-wavy about which equilibria obtain and why they align with ‘mostly-great’. Dead weight: Minimal. Single-issue: Focused on one mechanism (strategic equilibrium makes errors less “easy”). Overall: A moderately interesting objection that trims one supporting pillar, but it doesn’t address other routes to ‘no easy eutopia’ and doesn’t establish that equilibrium dynamics generally yield mostly-great outcomes, so it’s not a major problem for the position.
title: Strategic power contests would generate institutions that prevent extreme moral failures
